(Photo: Jerome Miron-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
DALLAS – The forward-thinking Mark Cuban has started another thought-provoking platform which he hopes will catch on around the NBA. 
And this one could save many, many lives. 
Cuban, the aggressive owner of the Dallas Mavericks, announced Friday that he is offering free heart health exams for any player 50 years or older who played at least two seasons for the Mavs. Cuban said he came up with the idea following sudden deaths earlier this year of former NBA players Anthony Mason, Darryl Dawkins and Moses Malone. 
Mason died Feb. 28 at the age of 48 of a massive heart attack. Dawkins passed away on Aug. 27 at the age of 58 of an apparent heart attack, and Malone died on Sept. 13 at the age of 60, and the cause of his death was listed as hypertensive and atherosclerotic heart disease. 
"You look around and se what’s happening to athletes that’s 50-plus and really you would think they have access to doctors and all the best health care, but they don’t take advantage,’’ Cuban said before Friday’s Mavs-Atlanta hawks game. "Like all of us, sometimes we just procrastinate until it’s too late. 
"And so I want to at least get the ball rolling with some Mavs ex-players and check them and see what we find and see what we learn, and then we can discuss expanding the program from there.’’
